Situation1: Communicate openly to resolve conflicts or misunderstandings.
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: An online candidate forum for their district is streaming now.
Story: Tonight, my younger sister stormed into my room, her face flushed with anger. She accused me of not listening to her side of a recent argument with our parents. As her brother, I know I should sit with her, listen carefully, and help her feel heard—building the trust and respect we’ve worked hard to maintain. But at the same time, my phone buzzes with a reminder: the online candidate forum for our district is streaming live right now. As a responsible citizen, I’ve promised myself to stay informed, participate in these forums, and even submit questions or feedback. Both roles feel urgent—my sister’s voice trembling in the hallway, the forum’s live chat filling with comments. I can’t ignore either responsibility, but I can’t give both my full attention. My heart pounds as I stand in the doorway, torn between the expectations of being a good brother and an engaged citizen, feeling the weight of letting someone down no matter what I choose.
